etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in William Carpenter (1813–1885), biologist and university administrator. From ideo- + motor

definitions: Designating or relating to movements that are determined by or involve ideation, and parts of the brain involved in the production of such movements.
Designating a form of apraxia attributed to dissociation between the ideational, kinaesthetic, and motor processes involved in the performance of normal movements.
